name: Afghanistan
currentCrisisSummary:
Since the US withdrawal and Taliban takeover in August 2021, Afghanistan endures widespread suffering driven by **economic collapse** and the dismantling of public services. This deep humanitarian emergency results directly from the freezing of central bank assets and broad financial restrictions imposed by Western powers, isolating the country and crippling its ability to function. Millions face acute food insecurity and malnutrition.

These **external economic pressures** â€” including the freezing of $7 billion in sovereign reserves â€” function as a form of **collective punishment**, drastically reducing state capacity and access to imports, with devastating consequences. The situation reverses fragile, **aid-dependent** development gains and fuels mass displacement and poverty.

The suffering is not merely an outcome of internal politics but is actively sustained by **international economic warfare**: **asset freezes**, **sanctions**, and financial exclusion have direct, measurable impacts. Addressing the crisis requires challenging these external **coercive measures**.

imperialRoot.imperialPower: Britain & Russian Empire (19th c. - 1919), USSR (1979-1989), US (2001-2021)
imperialRoot.legacy:
Afghanistan's fragility is embedded in a long history of **foreign intervention**. The 19th century '**Great Game**' between empires reshaped politics. **Soviet intervention** (1979-1989) and **Cold War proxy struggles** precipitated conflict and **state collapse**. The **US intervention** after 2001 created a hollow, **aid-dependent rentier state**. This project was fundamentally **neoliberal**, prioritising **privatisation**, outsourcing to **foreign contractors**, and imposing a market model fuelling corruption.

Each intervention reshaped institutions, entrenching **dependency** and fragmenting governance. Repeated external remaking has been a **structural driver** of instability.

historicalContext.title: The "Graveyard of Empires" Myth
historicalContext.description: This trope obscures sustained **foreign interference**. Successive **imperial** campaigns sought to reorder Afghan society for external aims, undermining local autonomy. Instability often results from repeated **external interventions** and extractive **geopolitical competition**.

historicalContext.title: The Opium Economy and the War on Drugs
historicalContext.description: The 20-year international presence coexisted with a massive **opium economy**. Western-led '**war on drugs**' strategies failed, criminalising poor farmers, enriching corrupt elites, and destabilising rural society by ignoring root causes.

historicalContext.title: Economic Pressure and Sanctions
historicalContext.description:
Post-August 2021 financial measuresâ€”notably **asset freezes** ($7B central bank reserves) and banking restrictionsâ€”constrained imports and public services. Multilateral and **unilateral sanctions** contributed to **economic contraction** and worsened living standards. These function as **economic coercion**, disproportionately punishing civilians.

These pressures compound **climate shocks** and displacement, producing a massive crisis.

historicalContext.title: International Law and Accountability
historicalContext.description: Beyond the current crisis, **accountability** is needed for harms from earlier interventions. Investigations document violations from **foreign military action**, **proxy support**, and **state collapse**. Documenting abuses is essential for redress.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands killed directly by conflict since 2001; far more suffer **indirect deaths** from healthcare collapse and malnutrition resulting from war and **economic blockade**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 23.7 million people require aid due to compounded effects of war, **sanctions**, and **state collapse**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Around 15.8 million face crisis-level food insecurity from **economic strangulation**, **aid dependency**, and **climate shocks**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 6.3 million internally displaced by decades of **foreign intervention**, conflict, **economic pressures**, and **climate breakdown**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 8.2 million Afghans forced into refugee situations by instability generated by **external interference**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Health facilities non-functional due to funding cuts linked to **international financial restrictions** and the legacy of an **aid-dependent system**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Deepening Poverty
humanitarianImpact.description: Extreme poverty surged post-2021 due to **sanctions** and the implosion of the **foreign-funded economy**.

timeline.event: **The Great Game**: A century of imperial rivalry between the British and Russian empires reshapes Afghan frontiers and politics, with three Anglo-Afghan wars and repeated interventions that undermine indigenous political autonomy.

**Independence, Modernisation and Interference**: Afghanistan achieves formal independence in 1919 but experiences recurring foreign influence and internal contestation as attempts to centralise and modernise are mediated by regional and imperial pressures.
**The Saur Revolution**: A coup brings the PDPA to power; radical social reforms and violent repression provoke widespread unrest.
**Soviet Invasion and Occupation**: The USSR intervenes militarily to support the PDPA, triggering a decade of war that causes mass death, displacement and the destruction of infrastructure.

**US Covert Support for Mujahideen**: The CIA's Operation Cyclone funds and arms insurgent groups resisting Soviet forces; this proxy warfare has long-term consequences for militancy and state collapse.
**Taliban First Rule**: The Taliban seize Kabul after civil war and impose a repressive regime that severely curtails rights, especially for women and girls.

**US Invasion & Occupation**: Following 9/11 the US and coalition forces overthrow the Taliban and initiate a two-decade intervention that channels vast resources into security, contracting and technocratic projects that deepen dependence on foreign aid and military spending.
**US Withdrawal & Taliban Return**: The chaotic US withdrawal in August 2021 precipitates the rapid collapse of the internationally backed government and the return of the Taliban to national power.

**Economic Warfare & Humanitarian Catastrophe**: International asset freezes and sanctions function as economic warfare, triggering state collapse and causing a deepening humanitarian catastrophe affecting tens of millions.

donate.description: A British humanitarian and development organisation working with deprived and excluded communities across Afghanistan.
Provides protection and assistance to refugees, returnees and internally displaced people from and within Afghanistan.
Focuses on providing education and protection for children, particularly girls, whose lives have been impacted by conflict and the economic crisis.
Delivers emergency food and nutrition support to communities across Afghanistan and is critical in preventing famine.

advocacy: Amplify Afghan civil society voices, especially women's rights activists, journalists and human-rights defenders.
Support Afghan-led organisations delivering aid and protection on the ground, and demand funding channels that enable direct, accountable transfers to local partners.
Advocate for the unfreezing or conditional, accountable release of sovereign assets to ensure civilians can access essential imports, salaries and public services.
Push for safe and legal routes for refugees and for humanitarian exemptions to sanctions that impede life-saving assistance.
Demand transparency and accountability for the costs and consequences of decades of foreign interventions and profiteering.

reading.title: *Ghost Wars: The Secret History of the CIA, Afghanistan, and Bin Laden, from the Soviet Invasion to September 10, 2001*
reading.description: Steve Coll's investigative account of US covert operations and their longer-term effects in Afghanistan.

reading.title: *No Good Men Among the Living: America, the Taliban, and the War Through Afghan Eyes*
reading.description: Anand Gopal's reporting on ordinary Afghans' experiences of war, occupation and the post-2001 political order.

reading.title: *The Afghanistan Papers: A Secret History of the War*
reading.description: Craig Whitlock uses confidential documents to expose the systemic failures and deceptions of the 20-year US war effort.
